Context: Hello
Response: Hello, how are you doing?

Context: I am hanging in there as well as I can be
Response: What's been going on?

Context: I am worried about losing my job. The company I work for has had layoffs and is talking about it again in a few months. This makes me really nervous
Response: It seems like that fear of losing your job has been taking a toll on you.

Context: It has indeed. I chose an industry that was fairly stable and a company that hadn't done layoffs in a long time but COVID changed all of that.
Response: Yeah, COVID is an unprecedented time where anything can happen. It must be frustrating knowing the safe path was taken but even then jobs might be taken away for something out of your control.

Context: Yes! Exactly and I cannot stand that. I love my routine and predicability.
Response: I can relate to that. It's always nice when everything falls into place. The prospect of a sudden change stresses me out and I imagine you've been feeling the same way as well. What's your fear if you lose your job?

Context: Very much so. If I lose my job I can't pay my bills and keep a roof over my head. In a good economy it took me over 300 applications, 50 interviews, and over 6 months to find a job.
Response: I think even if you lose your job, you would still be able to obtain resources through unemployment or even a stay at home temporary job from an employment agency while you look for another one or for your company to return to normal.

Context: I would hope so
Response: I can definitely relate. I've submitted around that many applications if not more before I found my current job. But working as a temp at other companies has helped me provide for myself in the meantime. :) You have every right to feel the way you do though. It's a scary time but know that things will be okay.

Context: Right. It's just not something I want to go through again. I just got this job 18 months ago. That job hunting dread and feeling hasn't gone away.
Response: I understand. It definitely is an agonizing process but you've gone through it before and have 18 months of experience under your belt from your current job which looks good on any resume. Despite the pandemic, I think this will help make things a lot easier for you.

Context: For the record, you are doing a really really good job. I really appreciate your time and kind words. Thank you for empathizing and relating. I appreciate your assistance. I feel a lot better about this now :)
Response: You are very welcome. (: It's my pleasure to help in any way I can.

Context: hello
Response: Hello, how are you doing today?

Context: I'm doing good and you
Response: I'm doing alright, thank you. I'm here for you if you'd like to tell me about anything going on in your life.

Response: A lot of people are in a tight bind right now with money... myself included. Do you need money to buy presents?

Response: Where do you want to take your friends and girlfriend?

Context: around my town, Just to enjoy ourselves for this new year celebration I am even bordered, I don' t like to be broke
Response: That is very sweet of you. Is there a more affordable place you can take them? That is very sweet of you. Is there a more affordable place you can take them?

Context: they will not like those small places
Response: It doesn't feel good to not have enough money to do the things you could normally do, but I'm sure that the people around you will be understanding. Do you live somewhere hot or cold? Maybe you can plan something based on enjoying nature.

Response: It seems like you feel like you will be a disappointment to your loved ones if you can't provide a special holiday celebration for them, is that right?

Response: How big of a party will it be?

Response: That seems like a lot of money to get quick, what part of the party will cost the most money?

Response: Maybe this year you could have a party in your home? And cook a lot of delicious food & ask people to bring their own drinks

Response: It sounds like you have to decide whether the party is important enough to borrow money for. Its been such a hard year for everyone, that a party could be good to raise everyone's spirits. However it could make your financial situation worse.

Response: Don't be afraid to ask the people you love for help! Bye

Context: I'm qualified for a promotion but my boss is refusing to promote me based on biased feedback he has received from someone else
Response: It sounds like you are having a hard time because your boss isn't willing to consider you for a promotion, is that right?

Context: Yes that's right. It's frustratgn *frustrating
Response: Have you talked to anyone else at work about it? I was in a similar situation once, I confided in a co-worker that I trusted and it gave me a different perspective.

Context: Unfortunately I can't really talk to anyone at work because there is no one I trust to this extent. Promotions are a bit of a sensitive issue
Response: Have you reported to your HR department the issue around biased feedback being used as a determining factor in not being considered?

Context: The HR department favours managers so I am worried that will damage my chances of promotion further
Response: I'm sorry you have to deal with this at work. I think you deserve the promotion because you are very dedicated.

Context: Thanks, that's good to hear
Response: I think if you continue to advocate for yourself in a positive manner you could possibly increase the chances of being considered for the promotion.

Context: It's hard to be positive when I feel like my manager is not receptive to my opinions and just trusts the feedback given by this one other person
Response: I've worked at a place that seems similar to your work environment. My co-workers were not supportive and I was always overlooked. Eventually, I realized that the environment was toxic and chose to start applying for different jobs. I felt like if my potential couldn't be appreciated then I should go somewhere with opportunities for growth.

Context: Maybe it is time for me to start looking elsewhere for better opportunities. I've worked at this place so long that I have become comfortable here and the thought of searching for a new job is intimidating
Response: You've got this! It's easy to become comfortable in what we know but, change causes us to grow.

Context: Yeah I agree, it's uncomfortable and difficult though! I haven't searched for a new job in so long, I feel like I will perform terribly at the interviews
Response: Just start slowly and remember that you can be picky about what position you chose. I also think we all feel like we perform badly during interviews. Preparation is key. I hope discussing your work situation today has made you feel a bit better!

Context: It has, thanks for being supportive and listening to my problem
Response: It was my pleasure! Thank you for sharing with me. I'm glad I had the opportunity.

Context: Hello
Response: Hi how are you?

Context: Im not doing very well at all.
Response: What's going on?

Response: I know the feeling. what do you do for work?

Context: I am a lab assistant.
Response: how long have you been in your role? and do you have any coworkers that feel similar to you that you know about?

Context: I have been in this role for about a year. I am the only one at this level. I take care of a lot of the productivity and logistical work. Im just really stressed recently
Response: Somewhat similarly I'm in a supply chain role, for a year now, and the only one at my level too. I often feel like I'm alone in my job and that I manage my boss... It's pretty frustrating. is there anything that makes your job less stressful?

Context: I think that being able to have a better work life balance would help but I have a hard time talking to my boss.
Response: do you think your boss would be receptive if you did talk to them? or would they dismiss your concerns?

Context: I am unsure. They are very much all about work. I am afraid they wont see my point and understand my want for a better work life balance.
Response: This has been a pretty hard year for everyone. however you ultimately gotta do whats best for you. Have you considered searching for a new job?

Context: I have but it is hard to find a job at this time. I also really like what I do but wish I could have more balance. Do you have any advice for how to balance stress at work and your life outside of work?
Response: I'm in the same boat. I would say, the things that work best for me, are to take breaks during my work day and go for walks or as soon as I'm done with work I force myself to go for a walk. I find moving helps me feel better. I also use that time to think about how I can look for a new job or rethink the things that are bothering me maybe you can try something similar?

Context: I think I could try that. I have a hard time detaching from work especially working from home. I feel like I never really 'leave' the office. I am always working even when I normally wouldnt be.
Response: Change the scenery, it'll help! plus movement releases endorphins which make you feel better.

Context: Thank you! I will try that.
Response: no problem!

Context: Hello
Response: Hello! How are you doing?

Context: I am anxious
Response: I'm sorry to hear that. What is the cause of your anxiety?

Context: My friends and my family place a lot of value on how one looks. Every time I meet with them they have a comment on how I should improve on something. It makes me stressed out because I feel like I am not good enough.
Response: I am sorry you are having to deal with this. Are you concerned about your own looks because you constantly hear this feedback from those close to you?

Context: Yes. I feel that I am not thin enough, pretty enough, that my clothes are not nice enough etc
Response: I myself have gone through similar feelings when I was a teenager. I had body image issues for the longest time and my way of resolving it was through proper diet and exercise. Are you happy with how you look personally irrespective of what others opinions are?

Context: It is hard to feel ok when I keep hearing that I am missing something. I don't even think I need to lose weight. It is just that my friends think model thin is what beauty is. I would have to starve myself to achieve that.
Response: If you are comfortable with your weight then why are you so concerned with what everyone around you says or thinks?

Context: Because they are the people I spend time with. I want to be accepted and I want them to like me.
Response: It sounds like you care more about what others think of you than how you feel about yourself.

Context: I wish I could not care about what they think but I do. I don't know how to not let their opinions not bother me
Response: Have you ever tried affirmations or heard of this before?

Context: No. What is that?
Response: Affirmations are positive statements you think about yourself. What I like to do when I'm feeling really anxious is say three positive things/attributes I feel about myself over and over again until my anxiety dissipates. Do you think that could help you feel more positively about what those closest to you are saying so much with regards to looks?

Context: I could try. Do I need to say positive things about my looks or can they be about other stuff?
Response: Since you are stating that you are concerned about how you look, you should just find a few positive statements with regards to your looks you think about yourself and repeat them. So if you don't think you need to lose weight, you can say something like, "I like my weight." or "I don't need to lose weight." If you think you are beautiful or pretty, you can say "I am beautiful." My three affirmations I use for myself are: I am beautiful, smart, and funny. I say this over and over again until my anxiety has left me.

Context: That sounds easy enough. I will definitely try it. It will take my mind off of worrying about what they are thinking.
Response: I highly recommend it! Is there anything else bothering you that I can help with?

Context: No you gave me a great suggestion to work with. Thank you so much for your help!
Response: No problem! Glad I could help. I hope you have a wonderful day and take care!

Context: You too. Bye now.
Response: Bye!

Context: Hello.
Response: Hi there, How are you doing today?

Context: I am angry today.
Response: Would you like to go into the reasons for why you are angry?

Context: I guess. I have a friend that is being really annoying and dismissive. I feel like they're not being a good friend.
Response: Do they act this way often?

Context: Not really, we were talking recently and she just didn't really want to hear my opinion and talked over me. Normally she's pretty good at listening.
Response: Well, everyone, including yourself, is entitled to an off day. Maybe something is going on with her she doesnt want to share. Or possibly even she is trying to share but doesnt know how.

Context: I guess that could be the case. What should I do then?
Response: Perhaps try to reach out and see if anything is wrong.

Context: So I should just ask her if something is going on?
Response: I would remember though, its ok for people to want to be left alone though if things are bad, sometimes they just need their space.

Context: Ok, that makes sense, I can get like that. What if something isn't wrong though?
Response: I would just say something along the lines of: Hey, youre not acting like yourself today, anything you want to talk about? I would see if there is anything you can do to help, if not just try and be as supportive as you can.

Context: Ok, that sounds like a good plan. I'm just a little worried that it won't work because she was acting really rude. So I feel like I don't really want to talk to her right now.
Response: Well, youre own health and well being does come first. If you feel it wont get anywhere, give her some space and come back to it at another date if you think you both would be comfortable with it.

Context: Okay. I think that sounds good. I'll give myself and hopefully her some time to calm down and then maybe ask if she want's to talk?
Response: That sounds like a solid plan.

Context: Thank you for helping! I feel a lot less upset and like I have an actual plan. You really helped me see that something could be going on with her that made her act so rude.
Response: I am glad i could help! Yeah, everyone including me, forgets that each individual has their own sets of things going on each day. Always good to look at it through their eyes a bit.

Context: Yeah, I think it's hard to do that when you're upset too.
Response: It definitely is. I guess thats what makes us human though. Take care!

Context: Hi!
Response: Good Afternoon. How are you doing today?

I feel very lonely without him.

Response: Having a playmate for the dog will make it easier to justify leaving when you do need to go back to work in the office. The puppy won't be lonely. I have a yellow lab! He's great!

Context: I hope to get a dog who enjoys working out with me like he did. Oh and I am not going back into an office! Not for awhile...probably not forever. I do have the option of staying home and working indefinetly so I am grateful for that.

Context: I like being here watching over my kids and pets. I think I will stay working at home.
Response: Just from talking to you, it sounds like working from home is a great fit for you!

Context: Pomeranian....he really didn't work out with me:), just running, jumping , and keeping up with my energy....doing what doggies do. His energy was happiness to me.
Response: Pomeranians are such cute dogs! They always look like they're smiling! And they're small enough that having two won't be crowded!

Context: I appreciate your feedback. I think that having two pomeranians this time is a good idea....and you are right they are always smiling! You have boosted my mood and made me feel hopeful. I thank you!
Response: I'm glad that I could help you! I hope your new puppies bring you much happiness! I think they will boost your spirits a lot!

Response: Yes, in the term "fake it until you make it." I keep on thinking of what could go right, or in my favor, and when I am done, it actually went okay, and any "fears" i had, never came to fruition.

I took a lot of walks and spent a lot of time with friends.

Context: I am feeling very sad right now, my boyfriend just broke up with me out of the blue
Response: I am so sorry that happened to you. It can be very difficult to cope with situations that seem they come out of nowhere. Did your boyfriend give you any reason for ending the relationship?

Context: He said he has been struggling with depression and needed to be alone
Response: Sometimes having depression can make a person feel that they need to seclude themselves. Were you aware that he felt this way?

Context: He has been distant recently.
Response: Unfortunately that can be a sign of depression or that something is going on. Have you been able to communicate with him previously about becoming distant?

Context: Every time I would bring it up he would dismiss it. I just don't know what to do. How can I get him back?
Response: Maybe you could try to talk to him about seeking help for depression? Talking to someone close to him or even a professional would help him immensely. Talking to a counselor would help him learn ways to cope with his feelings.

Context: That is a good idea. I want him to get back to being himself. He is like a different person right now. It's scary.
Response: I understand completely. Depression runs in my family and if it goes untreated, can scare anyone that is involved. You can try suggesting that he talks to a close friend, family member, or counselor to talk about how he is feeling and ways to cope with it. Sometimes medication could be a good way to fix the chemical imbalance that can cause depression.

Context: I will try to help him, he just doesn't want to seem to talk to my anymore. Do you have any suggestions on how to approach it with him?
Response: You could start a conversation by saying that you just want to check on him and see if he is okay and how he is doing. You don't want to start the conversation by immediately telling him to get help, as he might just get defensive.

Context: That is a good approach. And you don't think I will further upset him?
Response: I don't believe it will upset him if you ease into suggesting that he should talk to someone he is close to or seeing a professional. Your main goal is to check on him and make sure that he is okay since he seems to want to be alone and not talk to anyone. Once he tells you how he is doing you could mention that even talking to someone about his thoughts and feelings could lift a weight off his shoulders. If he seems that he doesn't really know why he feels the way does, you could suggest that medically speaking, sometimes our brains don't produce the chemicals that we need them to and it could make us feel bad. Seeing a professional to get their opinion would also help greatly.

Context: I agree, I hope he is agreeable to all of this. I just miss him so much and want him back.
Response: It's very hard to see someone we care about go through this. Communication is one of the best medicines there is to help someone feel better.

Context: I just hope he opens up to me, and if not me, someone who can help him.
Response: Even just trying to talk to him to see how he is doing will show him that care about him. I'm sure that once he is talking to someone about his thoughts and feelings, he will start to get back to his old self.

It was nice talking with you, and I do hope I helped you feel more in control of your next business venture. It's okay to feel that anger at your (former) friend, too. Use that feeling to work through things and I'm sure you'll be feeling more optimistic soon.

Response: It's great to try to integrate it into your day. All of us tend to have at least a few moments each day to ourselves. Even if it's during a shower or bathroom break, you really can meditate anywhere! It's all about being in the here and now.

Context: so true
Response: When things get stressful, meditation can be difficult. Sometimes we get wrapped up so much in our emotions that trying to center yourself and focus on your breathing and the moment can be hard. One thing I've learned to be helpful when I'm stressed is to breathe in through my nose while internally counting to three and out through my mouth counting to three. The counting tends to distract my mind from whatever stressful thing I was thinking of before.

Context: i like that thank you for the tip i must use that more often
Response: You're welcome! Is there anything else you'd like to talk about?

Context: no that will be thanx for listening to me
Response: My pleasure! I hope things start to look up for you. This has been a difficult time for all of us, but we'll pull through together! Nice speaking with you. Have a great day!

Context: Hello
Response: Good afternoon! What can I help you with today?

Context: I've been feeling a lot of pressure and stress lately due to school
Response: Oof, yes, school can be a tough situation. Are you close to the end of the semester? That can be both a relief and stressful, because a break is near, but all the exams and projects are due.

Context: Yes, I am a little more than halfway done with the semester The thing is that I am in a doctoral program, so even though the semester is close to the end, I always need to continue working
Response: Ahh, I see. That is a great deal of time and work. What are you studying?

Context: It is... I am in psychology I have to work on my thesis on the side even with all of my classes and I have a hard time managing my time and keeping track
Response: Time management can be very difficult with a normal class load, that sounds exhausting.

Context: It is!
Response: Do calendars help you at all? I am a super visual person, so calendars and planners are invaluable to me, as well as different colors of ink and labels so I can visually divide my attention Getting a million different colors of pens and highlighters changed my organization for the better.

Context: I do keep a physical and electronic agenda, but I feel like even if I write down my tasks, I find a way to procrastinate which is what I am having trouble with
Response: Also, setting clear boundaries for your study/work and relax times may help. I like to set a timer for, say, 45 minutes, and work/write/read/study for that long, then, I get a 10 minute break. I'll go outside, refresh my coffee, grab a snack, dance to some music, stretch, then set another timer for 45 minutes, then another break for 10 minutes. That allows my brain to take a second and refresh from the work.

Context: That is actually very helpful, I'll take note of it I think it would help to fix break times so I can actually focus on working
Response: Or, like, today, I woke up and spent half an hour allowing myself to drink my coffee and scroll through Reddit. Then it was time to work on my group project for 45 minutes, then a break, then I worked again, took a break, went to a class, etc. Scheduling your breaks can be helpful too so your lizard brain doesn't freak out and go "WE ARE GOING TO BE WORKING FOREVERRRR"

Context: I agree!!! That really is helpful, thank you
Response: which, for me at least, is where the fatigue sets in. You're very welcome! I hope I was helpful. You seem positive and willing to try new things, and I think you will be successful even if you are tired.

Context: Hm, I think it has less to do with liking or disliking, and more with starting a very hard and lengthy degree online without any social contact
Response: Ah, yes, that makes sense. And working from home is infamously hard, again, for lack of boundaries, so in addition to just not seeing people and getting the casual affirmation and confirmation messages on a daily basis of like "hey Jim you did a great job on that spreadsheet" or "Haha Jessica you're so funny", we also are writing papers in our pajamas and bedclothes, which makes it seem interminable.

Context: Ugh exactly
Response: Listening to lectures while the doorbell is ringing and it's just so strange and we aren't set up to do it. That's why I'm a big fan of specific spaces in my house since March. I tried to sit in bed with my laptop and do things but 1. I'm old and it hurts my wrists and 2. my headspace is so completely different from being my computer chair and at my desk. I try to be really strict about where I do my work., maybe trying to structure that a bit could help you feel a little more in control of the work load and your day's schedule.

Context: I agree, that makes a lot of sense! Thank you You have been a big help today and I really feel listened and understood. I really appreciate it
Response: I am very glad to hear that! You sound motivated to succeed and I think that you deserve to take care of yourself and stay healthy to complete your studies. It will be hard but it will also be worth it, and you should be proud. Good luck with everything!

Context: Wow, thank you! Have a great day
Response: Thank you! You too!

Context: Hey.
Response: Hello, what's on your mind today?

Context: Just wondering what I can do to deal with my cocky annoying friend Rick and his new car (as above)
Response: How long have you been friends?

Context: 30+ years since high school
Response: And he has always had cocky attitude? Have you ever told him that?

Context: He has, and yes I've told him, he just dismisses it, thinks it's funny that I get jealous
Response: I understand your frustration, it's upsetting when they dismiss what you say even though you have been friends for so long.

Context: Thanks.
Response: What I would recommend in this case is, spend more time with other friends who appreciate you. You also need to tell Rick your honest thought, don't beat around the bush but let him know you're serious

Context: That's good advice! Thanks. I wonder how I can get through to him to really let him know I'm serious. Ideas?
Response: I have been in the same situation myself, what I usually do is sit down with them and start the conversation in a serious mood. Explain everything I need to say and tell them that I mean every word. If they don't seem to accept and change, I keep my distance from them

Context: Makes sense. Unfortunately we live on the same street so it's kind of hard not to run into each other. :/
Response: That's even easier to make it clear, if you run into him, just give him a polite greetings. The point is, make it clear you have had enough

Context: Right, so basically let him know if he continues to act like he does, we're done as friends, correct? Or should I not be that bold?
Response: Yes. Be not too harsh at first. I would say to give him 1 more chance. If he still doesn't respect your words, it's the best for both to say it clearly.

Context: Sounds good, I'm looking forward to getting this resolved. Now I just have to work on the wording (what I'll say) to come across as serious without being too harsh, I guess. Suggestions welcome! :)
Response: You have the right mindset! Practice before talking will help you deliver your thoughts better.

Context: Yeah I tend to get too emotional lol
Response: I would start with something along the line "Look, I know we have had this conversation many times. However, i feel as though you never take me seriously. I want to say this one last time...."

Context: That's perfect. Copying that down right now! Seriously!
Response: Getting emotional is totally fine, that's why you need practice

Context: True it's just we've been friends for so long it would suck if we weren't anymore. So I've got a plan and know what to do. You've been super helpful! Thanks!
Response: I understand, it's difficult to come to this decision when you've been friends for so long. I hope he appreciates your friendship just as you do and tries his best.

Context: We will see!
Response: You're very welcome. is there anything I can do for you?

Context: No, I think that's it! Much appreciated!
Response: I think you can end our session here. I'm glad I could help a bit

Context: I am very upset
Response: Hello, how are you doing today? Im sorry to hear your upset. Do you want to go into why you are?

Context: A friend of more than 20 years hurt me deeply by judging me for not buying a gift for my nephew for his birthday.
Response: Why would they judge you on that? Do they know your nephew as well?

Context: Yes, she is very close friends with my nephew's mother as well. She is the kind of person who will go into deep debt and overdraw her bank account to buy someone a gift, I am not. I could not afford the gift, I am disabled and on a very minimal income.
Response: That i can relate too, i am also disabled and on SSI. Have you spoken to her about how she upset you?

Context: I did. I took a few days to cool off and then told her that her comments hurt me. I know that she's aware of my financial situation as well as the fact that I am disabled. Her response was that she said nothing wrong.
Response: Thats a tough spot to be in with a friendship that has lasted so long. Does she tend to treat you like this regularly?

Context: No, she really never has. Typically, she feels like other people walk all over her and take advantage of her, but that's never been me and its never been our relationship.
Response: Then would you say its a little odd for her to be acting in this manner towards you?

Context: Yes, quite. At times over the years she can become quite self absorbed. But she's never been so downright hurtful. I can't really see a way for our relationship to be the same anymore.
Response: I would agree that the relationship is getting a bit toxic but before terminating such a long relationship i would do one thing. I would try to see if there is something going on in her life right now for her to be acting like this. Sometimes people dont know how to talk about something thats bothering then and it in turn comes out as anger or spite.

Context: That's true. We've been through a lot together over the years. But I can't deny that what she said hurt, and our conversations are just so superficial now.
Response: Yeah to be honest if you press the issue and ask if anything is going and you continue to get toxic responses. It might be time to end the friendship. I would do that as a last resort but there is no need for you to be carrying it one sided and holding all the burden as well. It hurts to have to end a long friendship but unfortunately sometimes it has to happen to keep yourself in a better spot.

Context: Hi and good afternoon Thank you for your time
Response: Hello, and good afternoon yourself. How are you?

Context: Doing pretty good. Struggling a little
Response: What is making you struggle?

Context: My situation involves our Daughter and Son-in-Law. He is not treating her well, rude, gaslighting and treating the dog better. He is also not very nice to our grandaughter This is confidential, Right?
Response: Yes, of course it is :). So we are talking about your daughter and her husband and their child together, right?

Context: Yes, He is a nice guy to others. At home he is so different.
Response: I understand, people can often show different sides depending on who is around. Do you have any reason to think your daughter or granddaughter are in physical danger?

Context: No, they are safe. He's, like I said, a nice guy. Our Daughter, we are very close and she would tell us.
Response: That's great news! It sounds as though you are just concerned about how she is sometimes being treat. Have you had any conversation with your daughter about their relationship?

Context: Yes, numerous. Like I said we are close to our daughter. She wants to stay together and talks with him. He stays for whatever reason. I wish he would talk to me, to us. We have offered. He knows that we care about him.
Response: And that is so important and good to know there is trust from his side, to me it sounds as though that could be an olive branch for you to try and establish a conversation with both of them. An open and positive communication is always the first step in resolving anything.

Context: We have tried this before when we visit and he appears receptive. Treats he well and then when we are gone. He falls back into he behaviour.
Response: I recently went though a similar exercise with a friend and her boyfriend. We sat down in a room and spoke about our feelings. We had ground rules first and everyone knew they could talk without being judged or escalating. Maybe you could suggest follow up conversations, re-cap about what was spoken about previously and they can both evaluate how they have progressed since then?

Context: Thats sounds like a good idea. We have talked with them individually. Now the next step. We shall see. Yeah consistency leads to accountability. I like the idea. Thank you.
Response: I believe you have both their interests in mind. You sound like a positive person and you are just concerned for all 3 people involved.

Context: For sure, she is our daughter and our granddaughter needs her daddy.
Response: I hope they will be well receptive of your suggestion for a follow up.

Context: Thank you. I have some good ideas after chatting with you.
Response: No worries, I'm grateful for your time as well. If there is nothing else, I hope it all goes well and you have a wonderful weekend :)

Context: Good morning
Response: Hello, good morning! How are you today?

Context: Not too bad just wanted to talk with you about my alcohol addiction if you don't mind.
Response: I would be happy to listen and help if I can :) When did you notice you had a problem with alcohol?

Context: The thing is I am drinking beer almost every day since I started to work from home. And with weather so nice in upcoming weeks I can't see myself stop drinking.
Response: How many beer a day do you typically drink?

Context: At least 4 pints. A lot of money goes on drinks as well.
Response: I see. So if I understand correctly, you are concerned because you are drinking more than you used to, more frequently, and you are afraid you cannot stop? And it's affecting you financially?

Context: Yes, that's right. And I know I should stop but I just got addicted.
Response: It's really great that you have the insight to see that it may be a problem...that awareness is the most important first step!

Context: Thank you for understanding
Response: I haven't experienced addictions but I have been supporting my daughter with her addiction for many years, and I have seen how challenging it's been for her. She has found AA very helpful, and gets a lot of support from her peers there. Have you tried going to an AA meeting?

Context: I think I am not quite confident in going somewhere in person. I don't want other people to see my addiction problem
Response: The thing about AA is everyone in the room will be understanding and nonjudgemental and supportive. And you can learn from them what has worked for them. And it's okay to sit quietly and just listen, you are not forced to participate actively. And...it's anonymous! They have a code, outside meetings nobody is to disclose that you were there.

Context: To be fair I am scared also to go such places. If somebody from work will see me I would get in real trouble as I am working from home and drinking.
Response: I can understand that being scary, keeping your job is essential. Whereabouts are you? (I'm in CAnada)

Context: I am in UK. Maybe you know some online courses you are aware of?
Response: Oh!! I just remembered. My daughter goes to meetings virtually because of the pandemic. I am pretty sure there would also be virtual AA meetings in the UK, via Zoom

Context: Oh that's great I will try then. Do you know if there are any fees?
Response: Hmm I am afraid I don't, have you tried a google search? That's a great idea, to find an online program of some sort, if AA does not appeal to you. And no, there are no fees, AA is completely free. And, you can get a sponsor, do you know about that?

Context: What do you mean by a sponsor?
Response: My daughter has a sponsor, it's an important part of AA (and optional). Her sponsor has been clean for over 20 years. She is there to support my daughter, and help her work her way through learning the 12 steps. Beacuse she's been through it, her sponsor is very understanding and supportive.

Context: Alright, Don't know if I need one yet. Will see eventually how it goes in AA.
Response: I wish you all the best in your journey. You are doing all the right things in both recognizing that you have a problem, and seeking information on ways to deal with it. I admire your insight.

Context: Thank you very much for you help. Now I know what I have to do. All the best to you.
Response: You are welcome, it was a pleasure speaking with you. All the best! You can do it :)

Context: Thank you, bye :)
Response: Bye :)

Response: Okay I understand. Tell me a little about that.

Response: That is unfortunate. How did you accumulate such debt?

Response: That's tough. It has personally affect me as well as my financial health as well. I know the frustration.

Context: So please tell me some advice
Response: Well to do so I need a little more information. Have you already taken any steps to help your situation? If so what steps have you taken?

Context: yes I arranged a loan in a bank
Response: Okay that is an excellent start. Now to avoid another debt later on. Do you have a job to work with the payments to pay back the loan?

Context: yes I works in a broad wide company. So I will manage
Response: If I may offer a suggestion. Have you thought of contacting a debt relief program? In some cases they can substantially reduce debt to something much more manageable.

Context: I am worried about being perfect on my job. I don't want to lose my job.
Response: I hear you are trying to be perfect on your job because you are worried about losing your job. How long have you been at your job?

Context: I have been working for about 4 months, but I just am not as fast at it as everyone else. I'm trying so hard working late and everything but it's never enough.
Response: That can be hard when you are working so hard to try to do your best. Can you consult with a supervisor or co-workers to get some help?

Context: Maybe I could ask my friend and co-worker for some tips. I'm a little embarrassed to do so, but don't know where to turn. I don't want to get fired.
Response: Asking for help isn't always a bad thing. I asked for help at my last job and they gave me someone to help out. I was so relieved.

Context: That's true maybe it could turn out for the better. But what if they see me as incompetant?
Response: I can see that you have worry of being seen incompetent but as long as you are doing your best, they have to see the efforts you are making as positive.

Context: That's a good way to put it.
Response: Sometimes deep breaths can help keep you calm when approaching others in an anxiety provoking situation.

Context: I will have to try that. That might help.
Response: Have you thought of doing additional work related trainings? Sometimes they can give suggestions to improve work abilities.

Context: That sounds great. Do you think my work would be supportive?
Response: Work can often pay for trainings or offer suggestions what may improve work strategies.

Context: Wow, I hope I can take advantage of that. I will have to check into that. Who should I approach at work?
Response: You could ask your immediate supervisor or sometimes Human resources for support.

Context: I can do that. I think I'll reach out tomorrow to Human Resources for some help.
Response: That sounds like a good plan to reach out for support. Is there anything else I can help with?

Context: No that should be all. I am feeling more confident in strategies to use to help me. Thanks
Response: You are very welcome.

I have usually gotten help from friends, or done my best to delay or remove other commitments from my life. As a last resort, I have sometimes had to accept that I would be getting less sleep than usual for a few days. Are there any other commitments that you can possibly delay or remove from your life while you prepare for your job interview?

You can decide that while you would like to get this new job, the world will not end if you don't get it, and you will worry less and have less stress. Also there is the classic technique of picturing your interviewer in their underwear. It makes them seem less imposing, and you can feel more confident. Do you think any of these ideas might help?

Context: Hello

Context: I am suffering from low mood and general depression. I don't know what is causing it or how to get over it but it is getting excited down (obviously) and there doesn't appear to be any real reason behind it.
Response: I'm sorry to hear that. Have you been feeling this way for a while now or is this a recent issue?

Context: I felt this way for a while actually isn't a recent change it's been building slowly over time.
Response: Have you been feeling worse in terms of your depression over this time or has the intensity of your feelings stayed pretty much the same?

Response: Ok so you have felt like this for a while and it is getting worse not better. The intensity of your feelings is getting stronger and you worry that this will continue to get worse.

Response: Firstly, you are not alone in feeling this way. Many people struggle with depression and it's good that you have reached out for help for this.

Context: Any suggestions on what to do about it?
Response: There are many reasons people have depression. It is a recognised medical condition and the good news is that there is help out there. The first step is recognising the problem.

Context: Ok well there is definitely a problem.
Response: Have you spoken to friends and family about this? do they know how much you are struggling with it at the moment?

Context: not really I don't want to bother other people with my problems.
Response: if people care about you then they will be happy to give you the time and listen to how you are feeling at the moment. I think it will be a really good move to speak to family or friends tell them how you are feeling and talk it through this might really help.

Context: Yeah maybe. I suppose nobody really understands but I could at least speak to them about it.
Response: everyone has problems and it is good to talk about them because a problem shared is a problem halved. It doesn't mean the problems will go away but it might help you understand them and then be able to deal with them better.

Context: I don't want to feel like this anymore. I'm willing to at least give it a go.
Response: I also think that it will be worse to get in touch with your doctor or a medical professional. these people are trained to deal with problems like yours and will be able to offer effective Solutions from a medical perspective.

Response: are you worried that speaking to a doctor will lead to you being given medication, and you don't want this?

Context: yes that's right I don't want to take any pills or anything like that.
Response: I know that some forms of depression are caused by an imbalance of chemicals in the brain and medication in these cases can help. Also psychologists can support with mental health which means that this would not be a rude day involves any medication at all potentially

Context: what do you mean be a rude day.
Response: apologies this was a typo by autocorrect. I meant to say that this would not be a route that involves any medication at all potentially

Context: ok thanks for explaining. I think I'll speak to my sister about this. if this doesn't help I'll look into making an appointment with the psychologist maybe.

Response: yes I think a practice exam would be a great way to put you at ease and help you work on anything you might need to freshen up on.

Context: What do you do when you are reminded of that situation or think about the person?
Response: The easiest thing that I did in my situation was obtained a new hobby. I took my anger out on my ex by joining Crossfit and interacted with that community. It helped me take my mind of from my ex.

Context: I've seen that Crossfit helps a lot of people. That is a good idea but it is kind of intimidating
Response: Crossfit may not be for everyone, but do you think a new hobby may help you? Have you taken one in recently?

Response: Painting is an excellent hobby. I can see that it's relaxing as well as help put your emotions into something physical.

Context: Yes. I usually do it while listening to podcasts. It is a great distraction

Context: I have but not many of my friends have been in the position I was or understand how I feel

Context: Personally I've heard that Reddit can be really toxic
Response: It can be, but seeing several posts in their groups, most offer advice or at least sympathy. It is kind of like what we are doing right now to be honest. Again, it is not for everyone, but it does offer a group to talk to during this pandemic lol.

Context: I guess I can at least try it. Thanks for all the great advice
Response: Only if you think it will help. Do you think it will?

Context: I think it might be at least comforting knowing people have the same experience.
Response: No problem. I really hope that I was able to help you at least. I am still available if you want to discuss further. Like I said, I know how it feels because my ex hid from me 2 years that she was seeing someone else, so I can relate with you.

Context: Hi. I'm a little stressed out at the moment over losing my job in the coming months.
Response: I'm sorry to hear about that! I can totally understand why you'd be stressed. Is it for certain that you will lose your job?

Context: The company I work for is winding down. i'm on the old side to be looking for a job and i'm likely going to have to accept a lower salary, a longer commute and a heavier workload. In other words, I have a job I love, close to where I live that is very manageable. I can't sleep and I'm insanely anxious all of the time.
Response: I can feel your anxiety, and I completely understand why you're feeling that way, but you don't know for sure that will be true. Have you started looking for a new job already?

Context: I started looking for a job last week. I had a transition meeting today to pass on the little bit of my work that will be left to another person. I have 2 children; one who just started college this fall and another who is a junior in high school. my elderly mother lives with me also so I can't sell my house any time soon and move into something smaller and cheaper. I feel really trapped at the moment.
Response: It definitely sounds like you're being overwhelmed with a lot of responsibilities along with your job loss. It's definitely a lot of things to deal with all at once, but it would help to break things down so they're more manageable. Do you have anyone close by who can help you out?

Context: i have friends and family close by. i don't like to burden people with my problems. I know i also don't adjust well to change and that doesn't help. breaking issues down into groups is helpful and may take away some of the enormity of everything.
Response: I understand completely. I used to bottle things up too, but I've learned that the people who love you won't think you're a burden if you ask for help or just to have someone blow off some steam. Changes are definitely scary, but they can also be a great opportunity to do something different. Is there anything you want to try doing?

Context: I've always been reluctant to ask for help or favors because i keep thinking there will always be a time down the road where i will need something more. it's helpful to have someone remind me that change isn't always a bad thing. thank you. I'll talk to some friends to see if anyone has some good budget cutting tricks. I'll continue to look for a job and i'll try to calm down a little for now.
Response: It sounds like you're very self-aware and I think your friends and family will be very willing to lend a hand.

Context: You too.

Context: and you as well.
Response: You're welcome! Have a great day.

Context: Have a great day too!

I'm worried about how the counselors will see me, how others at a facility might view me, and any one else that I will have to share my story with when getting treatment and how they might view me. I'm ashamed of myself, my life, and the choices that I've made that have gotten me here and I guess my problem is that I just dont know how to get over these extreme anxieties and worries so that I can just finally make the step that I need so desperately and get help.

Response: What level of alcohol consumption do you have?

Response: From what I've seen, people who can use some of these strategies like deep breathing and counseling they have felt some relief and could move forward better toward their goals.

Response: Hi there, how can I help you?
